I could use a conditional clean-up in tearDown, for exactly the same reason
as Brian.

When I first ran into this issue; I didn't think of trying to make the
tearDown() clean-up conditional.  Instead, I adopted a convention of having
my setUp()s perform the clean-up for the next test.  In other words, for a
given test I do a pre-clean instead of a post-clean.  I'm not sure if that's
good or bad...

Kendall

----- Original Message -----
From: Brian br524-at-yahoo.com br524-at-yahoo.com |Yahoo Work 20030102|
To: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 10:47
Subject: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()


I only have one test in the TestCase, and if it fails, I want to leave
the database in the state it was in when the test failed so I can
inspect what happened.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> Brian  wrote:
>
> >I see in the TestResult class there's a method wasSuccessful().
From
> >within class that extends TestCase, I want to do something like
this:
> >
> >    public void tearDown()
> >    {
> >        TestResult result = createResult();
> >        if( result.wasSuccessful() )
> >        {
> >            System.out.println( "Clearing database" );
> >            clearDatabase( "1" );
> >        }
> >    }
> >
> >
>
> Is this intended to be more efficient than just clearing the
database
> every time the tearDown() method is invoked, or am I missing
something?
>
> Mike
